elements.content: The paper reports on four novel solid-state architectures constructed by using tectons having the general formula:  [Cr(AA)(C2O4)2]- [AA = 2,2‘-bipyridine (bipy) and 1,10-phenanthroline (phen)]. These building blocks are involved in various intermolecular interactions:  coordinative, hydrogen bonds, and π−π contacts. Two new crystallohydrates in the Ba[Cr(AA)(C2O4)2]2·nH2O family have been characterized:  [BaCr2(bipy)2(C2O4)4(H2O)2]·4H2O (1) and [BaCr2(phen)2(C2O4)4(H2O)2] (2). Because of the different numbers of water molecules, their crystal structures are completely different from those of two others previously reported, [BaCr2(bipy)2(C2O4)4(H2O)]·H2O and [BaCr2(phen)2(C2O4)4(H2O)2]·4H2O. The crystal structure of 1 consists of neutral chains, with diamond-shaped units sharing the barium atoms, with the two other corners occupied by chromium atoms. The barium and chromium ions are connected by bis(bidentate) oxalato ligands. Compund 2 exhibits a two-dimensional structure with irregular octagonal meshes. The Ba(II) and Cr(III) ions are connected by two types of oxalato bridges:  bis(bidentate) toward chromium and barium, and bidentate toward chromium, monodentate toward barium. The supramolecular solid-state architectures of two new Mn(II)−Cr(III) heteropolymetallic systems are discussed:  [Mn(4,4‘-bipy)2(H2O)4][Cr(phen)(C2O4)2]2·9H2O (3) and [Mn(MAC)(H2O)2][Cr(phen)(C2O4)2]2 (4) [4,4‘-bipyridine = 4,4‘-bipy, MAC = a pentaaza macrocyclic ligand, 2,13-dimethyl-3,6,9,12,18-pentaazabicyclo-[12.3.1]octadeca-1(18),2,12,14,16-pentaene]. These complexes have been obtained from the corresponding barium precursors through transmetalation reactions, in the presence of organic ligands (4,4‘-bipy or the macrocyclic ligand, MAC). The cationic entities in 3, [Mn(4,4‘-bipy)(H2O)4]2+, are interconnected through O−H···N hydrogen bonds and face-to-face π−π stacking interactions between pairs of 4,4‘-bipy ligands affording supramolecular chains. Crystal 4 is built up by cationic, [Mn(MAC)(H2O)2]2+, and anionic, [Cr(phen)(C2O4)2]-, entities. Each aqua ligand from the cationic units is hydrogen bonded to two oxygen atoms arising from the oxalato ligands belonging to two different anionic species, resulting in supramolecular chains. The cryomagnetic properties of the two Ba−Cr polynuclear complexes have been investigated. Very weak antiferromagnetic interactions occur between the chromium(III) ions in 1 and 2.

elements.content: Oxalato-bridged heteropolynuclear complexes have played an important role in the development of chemistry of molecular solids with interesting physical properties (magnetic, electric, or optical). Various compounds, ranging from oligonuclear species to high dimensionality (one-, two-, and three-dimensional) systems, were constructed by using anionic oxalato complexes as building blocks and a large diversity of assembling cations (complexes with potentially free coordination sites).
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Oxalato-bridged heteropolynuclear complexes have played an important role in the development of chemistry of molecular solids with interesting physical properties (magnetic, electric, or optical). Various compounds, ranging from oligonuclear species to high dimensionality (one-, two-, and three-dimensional) systems, were constructed by using anionic oxalato complexes as building blocks and a large diversity of assembling cations (complexes with potentially free coordination sites).

elements.content: In a series of papers, we have shown that bis-oxalato complexes of chromium(III), [Cr(AA)(C2O4)2]- [AA = 2,2‘-bipyridine (bipy), 1,10-phenanthroline (phen), 2,2‘-bipyrimidine (bpym), 2,2‘-dipyridylamine (dpa)], are extremely versatile building blocks for the synthesis of heteropolynuclear complexes with a rich variety of structures. The self-assembly processes involving these species and mono- or dipositive cations led to two series of heteropolynuclear complexes:  [MICr(bipy)(C2O4)2(H2O) x ] (M = K, Na, Ag) and [MIICr2(bipy)2(C2O4)4(H2O) y ] (M = Ba, Mn, Co, Ni, Cu). Within each series, completely different structures have been obtained, according to the coordination algorithm of the assembling cation. We have also shown that the structures of the heterometallic complexes can be further influenced by using ancillary ligands attached to the assembling cation. For example, the reaction between Mn2+(aq), 2,2‘-bipyridine, and [Cr(phen)(C2O4)2]-, in the presence of sodium oxalate, led to a tetranuclear [CrIII−C2O4−MnII−C2O4−MnII−C2O4−CrIII] complex. Other authors have illustrated the ability of [Cr(bipy)(C2O4)2]- to act as a ligand toward lanthanide cations. The starting materials in most cases are BaII−CrIII complexes, [BaCr2(AA)2(C2O4)4(H2O) n ]·mH2O, which are reacted with metal sulfates to afford the coresponding heterometallic species.

elements.content: The crystal structure of two barium precursors, [BaCr2(bipy)2(C2O4)4(H2O)]·H2O and [BaCr2(phen)2(C2O4)4(H2O)2]·4H2O, have already been described. The first one is a scaffolding-like material with a three-dimensional (3-D) structure and ten-coordinated barium ions. The crystal structure of the phenanthroline derivative consists of heterometallic chains with the two oxalato groups of the chromium brick coordinated to two barium ions. The barium ions are also ten-coordinated. In this paper, we show that a different number of water molecules causes important structural modifications in these oxalato-bridged BaII−CrIII compounds. Two new crystallohydrates, [BaCr2(bipy)2(C2O4)4(H2O)2]·4H2O (1), and [BaCr2(phen)2(C2O4)4(H2O)2] (2), are described. In previous papers, we reported on the synthesis of oxalato-bridged Mn(II)−Cr(III) which are obtained through transmetalation reactions between the barium precursors and manganese sulfate. We present here two new supramolecular MnII−CrIII heteropolymetallic systems of formulas [Mn(4,4‘-bipy)2(H2O)4][Cr(phen)(C2O4)2]2·9H2O (3), and [Mn(MAC)(H2O)2][Cr(phen)(C2O4)2]2 (4), which are obtained by attaching ancillary ligands to the manganese(II) ions [4,4‘-bipy = 4,4‘-bipyridine, and MAC = a pentaaza macrocyclic ligand, 2,13-dimethyl-3,6,9,12,18-pentaazabicyclo-[12.3.1]octadeca-1(18),2,12,14,16-pentaene].

elements.clean_text:
Experimental Procedures

 Syntheses. All manipulations were performed using reagents and solvents as received. Compound [BaCr2(bipy)2(C2O4)4(H2O)]⋅H2O and the manganese(II) precursor, [Mn(MAC)(H2O)2]Cl2⋅4H2O, have been prepared according to the literature.

elements.content: [BaCr 2 (bipy) 2 (C 2 O 4 ) 4 (H 2 O) 2 ] · 4H 2 O (1), was synthesized as follows. A total of 0.1 g of [BaCr2(bipy)2(C2O4)4(H2O)]·H2O was dissolved in 100 mL of water and the resulting red solution was left to evaporate at room temperature. Red prisms of 1, which were suitable for X-ray diffraction appeared in a few days. Anal.:  calcd for C28H28BaCr2N4O22 (1):  C, 33.14; H, 2.76; N, 5.52. Found:  C, 33.6; H, 3.02; N, 5.84. IR (KBr, cm-1):  3459 (m), 1714 (vs), 1685 (s), 1655 (s), 1446 (m), 1387 (s), 1253 (m), 1032 (w), 897 (w), 808 (m), 768 (m), 662 (w), 548 (s).

elements.content: [Mn(4,4‘-bipy) 2 (H 2 O) 4 ][Cr(phen)(C 2 O 4 ) 2 ] 2 · 9H 2 O 3. A suspension of 2 (1.0 mmol) in 10 mL of water was reacted with the stoichiometric amount of MnSO4·H2O (1.0 mmol) dissolved in 10 mL of water. The resulting mixture was stirred for 4 h to promote the complete precipitation of the barium sulfate, which was removed by filtration. An ethanolic solution of 4,4‘-bipyridine (2.0 mmol, 10 mL) was added to the red filtrate and the resulting solution was left undisturbed at room temperature. A first crop of red-violet prisms of 3 were formed after one week. Anal.:  Calcd for C52H58Cr2MnN8O29 (3):  C, 44.01; H, 4.09; N, 7.89%. Found:  C, 44.17; H, 4.15; N, 7.9%. elements.content: X-ray Diffraction Studies. Diffraction data on single crystals of 1 and 2 were collected on and Bruker Smart CCD diffractometer by using graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation with a nominal crystal to detector distance of 4 cm. A hemisphere of data was collected based on three ω-scan runs [starting ω = −28 (1) and −30° (2)] at values of φ = 0°, 90°, and 180° with the detector at 2θ = −28° (1) and −30° (2). At each of these runs, frames (606, 435, and 230, respectively) were collected at 0.3° intervals (1 and 2) and 10 (1) and 15 s (2) per frame. The diffraction frames were integrated using the SAINT package and corrected for absorption with SADABS. The maximum and minimum transmission factors were 1.9548 and 1.3704 for 1 and 1.9554 and 1.3619 for 2. Pertinent details for the structure determination and refinement of 1 and 2 are summarized in Table together with those of compounds 3 and 4.

The structures of 1 and 2 were solved by direct methods through the SHELXTL 5.1016 program package and subsequently refined by Fourier recycling. The non-hydrogen atoms of 1 and 2 structures were refined anisotropically. The hydrogen atoms of the bipyridine ligand in 1 were calculated and refined isotropically as riding atoms, whereas those of water molecules were neither found nor calculated. The hydrogen atoms except hydrogen atoms on O(9) in 2 were found in a difference Fourier map and refined isotropically. The final full-matrix least-squares refinement on F 2, minimizing the function ∑w(|F o| − |F c|)2, reached convergence at the values of the discrepancy indices listed in Table . The final geometrical calculations and graphical manipulations were carried out with the XP utility of the SHELXTL 5.10 systems. Selected bond distances are gathered in Table .

Two New Crystal Architectures with the [BaCr 2 (AA) 2 (C 2 O 4 ) 4 (H 2 O) n ] · m H 2 O Systems (AA = 2,2‘-Bipyridine; 1,10-Phenanthroline). The two new BaII−CrIII compounds, [BaCr2(bipy)2(C2O4)4(H2O)2]·4H2O (1), and [BaCr2(phen)2(C2O4)4(H2O)2] (2), differ from those previously reported ([BaCr2(bipy)2(C2O4)4(H2O)]·H2O and [BaCr2(phen)2(C2O4)4(H2O)2]·4H2O) through the number of water molecules.

Results and Discussion

 Two New Crystal Architectures with the [BaCr  2  (AA)  2  (C  2  O  4  )  4   (H  2  O)   n   ]  ⋅   m  H  2  O Systems (AA = 2,2‘-Bipyridine; 1,10-Phenanthroline). The two new BaII-CrIII compounds, [BaCr2(bipy)2(C2O4)4(H2O)2]⋅4H2O (1), and [BaCr2(phen)2(C2O4)4(H2O)2] (2), differ from those previously reported ([BaCr2(bipy)2(C2O4)4(H2O)]⋅H2O and [BaCr2(phen)2(C2O4)4(H2O)2]⋅4H2O) through the number of water molecules.

elements.content: The crystal structure of 1 consists of neutral chains, with diamond-shaped units sharing the barium atoms, while the two other corners are occupied by chromium atoms. The asymmetric unit is depicted in Figure . The barium ions are connected through [Cr(bipy)(C2O4)2]- ions, with the oxalato groups exhibiting the classical bis-bidentate bridging mode (Figure ). The coordination number of barium is ten:  eight oxygen atoms arising from the four oxalato bridges and two aqua ligands. The Ba−O distances vary between 2.758(3) and 2.878(3) Å. The O−Ba−O bite angles of the bis-bidentate oxalato ligands are very acute [58.56(8)−58.35(8)°]. The chromium atom is coordinated by two bipy nitrogen and four oxygen atoms, adopting a distorted octahedral geometry. The short bites of the bipy [79.0(1)°] and oxalato ligands [83.1(1) and, respectively, 83.2(1)°] are the main factors responsible for the distortion of the [CrN2O4] chromophore. The Cr−N bond distances [2.053(3) and 2.048(3) Å] are somewhat longer than the Cr−O(ox) ones [1.950(3)−1.969(3) Å]. The shortest intrachain metal−metal separations are Ba···Cr = 6.121, Cr···Cr = 12.24, Ba···Ba = 9.511 Å. The chromium moieties within a chain have the same chirality. Consequently, each chain is chiral. Chains of opposite chiralities, related by a center of inversion, are present in the crystal. The neighboring chains interact through π−π contacts established between the bipy ligands [3.6 Å] (Figure ). This structure is very similar to the one of the phen derivative, [BaCr2(phen)2(C2O4)4(H2O)2]·4H2O. The same topology of the metallic centers was found in two other oxalato-bridged heterometal complexes:  [Mn{Cr(bipy)(C2O4)2}2]3 and [Sr{Cr(dpa)(C2O4)2}2]·8H2O.

elements.content: The single-crystal X-ray investigation of the second BaII−CrIII compound, [BaCr2(phen)2(C2O4)4(H2O)2], reveals a two-dimensional (2-D) framework, which is made up of crystallographically independent heterotrinuclear entities of formula [Ba(H2O)2{Cr(phen)(C2O4)2}2], with two different chromium atoms, Cr(1) and Cr(2) (Figure ). The structure can be described as follows:  the barium ions are connected through [Cr(1)(phen)(C2O4)2]- ions, with both oxalato groups acting as bis-bidentate ligands, resulting in zigzag chains running along the crystallographic b axis. These chains are then interconnected by [Cr(2)(phen)(C2O4)2]- ions, from which one oxalato group acts as a bis-bidentate ligand, while the second one acts as a bidentate ligand toward chromium and as a monodentate ligand toward barium. It results in a 2-D network, with irregular octagonal meshes, which are filled by stacked phenanthroline ligands belonging to two adjacent chromium units (Figure ). The separation between the two phen planes is ca. 3.28 Å. The barium atoms exhibit a coordination number of nine:  seven oxalato oxygen atoms and two aqua ligands. The Ba−O distances range between 2.775(4) and 2.920(4) Å. The chromium chromophore, [CrN2O4], displays the characteristic features observed with other heteropolymetallic systems constructed from the [Cr(phen)(C2O4)2]- building block. The intermetallic distances within a mesh are Ba(1)−Cr(1) = 5.985; 6.033 Å; Ba(1)−Cr(2) = 5.980; 6.616 Å. The longest distance corresponds to the metal ions bridged by the bidentate-monodentate oxalato group. This bridging mode of the oxalato ligand, considered until recently as quite unusual, is already illustrated by several compounds. Selected bond distances for compounds 1 and 2 are collected in Table .

elements.content: The number of water molecules (coordinated and uncoordinated) is crucial for the dimensionality of the oxalato-bridged BaII−CrIII frameworks. In the case of the oxalato-bridged BaII−CrIII−bipy system, the highest dimensionality, 3-D, is observed with the [BaCr2(bipy)2(C2O4)4(H2O)]·H2O compound, with one aqua ligand to barium. If the number of aqua ligands coordinated to barium increases to 2, then a one-dimensional coordination polymer is obtained:  [BaCr2(bipy)2(C2O4)4(H2O)2]·4H2O (1), whose structure is similar to the one of the phenanthroline derivative, [BaCr2(phen)2(C2O4)4(H2O)2]·4H2O, with the same number of water molecules. Compound 2, [BaCr2(phen)2(C2O4)4(H2O)2], with only two water molecules, both coordinated to barium, exhibits a 2-D structure.

In the case of the oxalato-bridged BaII-CrIII-bipy system, the highest dimensionality, 3-D, is observed with the [BaCr2(bipy)2(C2O4)4(H2O)]⋅H2O compound, with one aqua ligand to barium. If the number of aqua ligands coordinated to barium increases to 2, then a one-dimensional coordination polymer is obtained: [BaCr2(bipy)2(C2O4)4(H2O)2]⋅4H2O (1), whose structure is similar to the one of the phenanthroline derivative, [BaCr2(phen)2(C2O4)4(H2O)2]⋅4H2O, with the same number of water molecules. Compound 2, [BaCr2(phen)2(C2O4)4(H2O)2], with only two water molecules, both coordinated to barium, exhibits a 2-D structure.

elements.content: Two Novel Supramolecular Polymetallic (Mn II − Cr III ) Architectures Sustained by Hydrogen Bond and π − π Stacking Interactions. The assembling processes involving the anionic building blocks, [Cr(AA)(C2O4)2]-, and transition metal ions, with or without ancillary ligands attached to them, lead to either genuine heteropolynuclear complexes, or to ionic compounds, in which both cation and anion are complex species. We describe herein two complexes belonging to the last category:  [Mn(4,4‘-bipy)2(H2O)4][Cr(phen)(C2O4)2]2·9H2O (3), and [Mn(MAC)(H2O)2][Cr(phen)(C2O4)2]2 (4) (MAC stands for the pentaazamacrocyclic ligand, resulting from the template condensation of 2,6-diacetyl-pyridine with triethylenetetramine). Compound 3 was obtained by reacting the Mn2+(aq) and [Cr(phen)(C2O4)2]- ions with 4,4‘-bipyridine.
elements.clean_text: Two Novel Supramolecular Polymetallic (Mn  II   - Cr  III   ) Architectures  Sustained by Hydrogen Bond and  π - π Stacking  Interactions. The assembling processes involving the anionic building blocks, [Cr(AA)(C2O4)2]-, and transition metal ions, with or without ancillary ligands attached to them, lead to either genuine heteropolynuclear complexes, or to ionic compounds, in which both cation and anion are complex  species. We describe herein two complexes belonging to the last category: [Mn(4,4‘-bipy)2(H2O)4][Cr(phen)(C2O4)2]2⋅9H2O (3), and [Mn(MAC)(H2O)2][Cr(phen)(C2O4)2]2 (4) (MAC stands for the pentaazamacrocyclic ligand, resulting from the template condensation of 2,6-diacetyl-pyridine with triethylenetetramine). Compound 3 was obtained by reacting the Mn2+(aq) and [Cr(phen)(C2O4)2]- ions with 4,4‘-bipyridine.

elements.content: 4,4‘-Bipyridine is a widely used tecton in constructing extended structures. It can act as bridging and terminal ligand, but can be found in the solid state as an uncoordinated guest molecule as well. The terminal and uncoordinated 4,4‘-bipy molecules can be involved in either hydrogen bond or stacking interactions. The solid-state architectures of the metal−4,4‘-bipyridine systems are strongly dependent on (1) the metal-to-ligand molar ratio; (2) the function accomplished by 4,4‘-bipy (bridging, terminal, uncoordinated); (3) the stereochemical preference of the metal ion; (4) the presence of solvent molecules acting as ligands and as possible hydrogen-bond donors, D−H, toward the terminal or uncoordinated 4,4‘-bipy molecules; (5) the role of the anions (coordinated, bridging, uncoordinated); (6) the presence of organic guest molecules. For the 1:2 metal-to-ligand ratio, the following cases have been described:25 (i) both 4,4‘-bipy molecules act as bridging ligands, resulting in either square-grid or diamondoid networks; (ii) one molecule acts as a bridging ligand, the other one being uncoordinated; it results in 2-D layers with rhombic meshes (Chart a); (iii) both 4,4‘-bipy molecules act as terminal ligands, and are involved in hydrogen-bond interactions with the aqua ligands from neighboring mononuclear entities, resulting also in 2-D layers (Chart b). The last case was illustrated by the heteropolymetallic systems [M(4,4‘-bipy)2(H2O)4][Cr(bipy)(C2O4)2]2·3H2O (M = Mn, Co, Ni). Interestingly, the solid-state supramolecular architecture of the phenan-throline derivative, [Mn(4,4‘-bipy)2(H2O)4][Cr(phen)(C2O4)2]2·9H2O (3), is completely different. It consists also of mononuclear ions, [Mn(4,4‘-bipy)2(H2O)4]2+ and [Cr(phen)(C2O4)2]- (Figure ), but the cationic entities are interconnected in a different way. The two terminal 4,4‘-bipy ligands from two neighboring cationic entities interact via π−π stacking through both aromatic rings (3.6 Å) (Chart c). This interaction is quite unusual:  most of the known examples of aromatic interactions between 4,4‘-bipy molecules acting as terminal ligands consist of face-to-face or offset contacts of the peripheral pyridyl rings. These interactions are sustained by the hydrogen bonds established between the aqua ligand from a cationic unit and the 4,4‘-bipy ligand from another one [O(18)···N(5) = 2.895 Å, O(20)···N(6) = 2.813 Å], resulting in supramolecular cationic chains (Figure ). The distance between the manganese(II) ions within a chain is 12.43 Å. Each manganese(II) ion is hexacoordinated by two nitrogen atoms arising from the trans-disposed 4,4‘-bipy molecules, and by four aqua ligands. The Mn−N distances are slightly longer than the Mn−O ones (Table ). As in many other complexes with 4,4‘-bipy ligands, the two pyridyl rings are not coplanar, the diehedral angle between them being 8.89°. The anionic units present the characteristic features already discussed. The two enantiomeric forms of [Cr(phen)(C2O4)2]- are present in the same crystal, being interconnected through aromatic interactions established between the phenanthroline ligands (3.54 Å). Moreover, the anionic and cationic entities interact through the stacking between the phen and 4,4‘-bipy ligands (3.5 Å).

elements.content: The crystallographic investigation of compound 4 shows that it is built up by cationic, [Mn(MAC)(H2O)2]2+, and anionic, [Cr(phen)(C2O4)2]-, entities (Figure ). The manganese(II) ions display a distorted pentagonal−bipyramidal geometry, with the macrocyclic ligand forming the equatorial plane. The Mn−N distances fall in the range 2.251(7) and 2.311(5) Å. The axial positions are occupied by the aqua ligands [Mn−O = 2.222(4) Å]. The analysis of the packing diagram of compound 4 reveals interesting features at the supramolecular level. Each aqua ligand from the cationic units is hydrogen bonded to two oxygen atoms arising from the oxalatoligands belonging to two different anionic species [O(4a)···O(9a) = 2.750; O(8)···O(9) = 2.828 Å], resulting in supramolecular chains. The supramolecular chains are further interconnected through π−π contacts established between the phen ligands (∼3.4 Å) − Figure .

The supramolecular chains are further interconnected through π-π contacts established between the phen ligands (~3.4 Å) - Figure .

Selected bond distances for compounds 3 and 4 are gathered in Table .

The diffuse reflectance spectra of the four compounds have been recorded. These are dominated by the d−d transitions of the chromium(III) chromophores, [CrN2O4]. The two bands observed in the UV−Vis spectra with the four compounds (1:  ν1 = 545; ν2 = 390; 2:  552, 379; 3:  545; 397; 4:  548; 378 nm) are assigned to the following transitions of chromium(III) in a (pseudo)octahedral environment:  4A2g → 4T2g and, respectively, 4A2g → 4T1g. The d−d bands of the manganese(II) chromophores (due to spin-forbidden transitions) are too weak to be observed or they are obscured by the d−d transitions of chromium(III).

elements.content: The temperature dependence of the χM T product for compounds 1 and 2 [χM is the magnetic susceptibility per mol of chromium(III)] in the temperature range 1.9−60 K is shown in Figures and . At 60 K, the values of χM T for both compounds (1:  1.81 cm3 mol-1 K; 2:  1.85 cm3 mol-1 K) are as expected for a magnetically isolated spin quartet (1.87 cm3 mol-1 K). As the temperature islowered, χM T decreases very slowly down to 20 K, then more and more rapidly, reaching a value of 1.52 cm3 mol-1 K (for 1) and 1.58 cm3 mol-1 K (for 2) at 1.9 K. The magnetic behavior of the two compounds might be due to one of the following causes, or to a combination of them:  (i) zero field splitting (D) of the ground state of Cr(III) ( H = D[ S z 2 − (1/3)S(S + 1)]); (ii) antiferromagnetic interaction (θ) between the chromium(III) ions through the oxalato−BaII−oxalato bridging skeleton and/or π−π contacts from the nitrogen heterocycles bipy and phen and/or intermolecular coupling. Least-squares analysis of the susceptibility data of 1 and 2 through eqs 1−3 with g, D, and θ as variable parameters provides a calculated curve that reproduces well the experimental data, but the value of D is unreasonable. The same procedure but making θ = 0 did not produce a good fit. Finally, the computed curve taking g and θ as variable parameters (D = 0) matches well the susceptibility data, with g = 1.98 (1) and g = 1.99 (2) and θ = −0.39 (1) and θ = −0.35 K (2). The weak magnetic couplings observed in 1 and 2 are in agreement with the large chromium−chromium separation[Cr···Cr = 12.24 Å (1) and Cr(1)···Cr(1) = 11.08, Cr(2)···Cr(2) = 12.58 Å (2)]. The examples presented here illustrate once more the richness of the chemistry generated by the [Cr(AA)(C2O4)2]- ions. In some respects, these ions behave like any other metal-free polyatomic anion, for example, SO4 2-, and they can accomplish various functions:  “free”, monodentate, bidentate, or bridging ligand. Moreover, the oxalato oxygen atoms may act as hydrogen-bond acceptors, while the bipy or phen ligands may be involved in π−π stacking interactions, with a key role in stabilizing the crystal lattice. In summary, the great versatility of the [Cr(AA)(C2O4)2]- as a ligand has already provided quite a large series of polymetallic assemblies in which the dimensionality of the crystal structures depends not only on the cation and ancillary ligands introduced but also on the number of solvent molecules (coordinated or uncoordinated) as shown here.

[BaCr 2 (bipy) 2 (C 2 O 4 ) 4 (H 2 O) 2 ] · 4H 2 O (1), was synthesized as follows. A total of 0.1 g of [BaCr2(bipy)2(C2O4)4(H2O)]·H2O was dissolved in 100 mL of water and the resulting red solution was left to evaporate at room temperature. Red prisms of 1, which were suitable for X-ray diffraction appeared in a few days. Anal.:  calcd for C28H28BaCr2N4O22 (1):  C, 33.14; H, 2.76; N, 5.52. Found:  C, 33.6; H, 3.02; N, 5.84. IR (KBr, cm-1):  3459 (m), 1714 (vs), 1685 (s), 1655 (s), 1446 (m), 1387 (s), 1253 (m), 1032 (w), 897 (w), 808 (m), 768 (m), 662 (w), 548 (s).

[BaCr 2 (phen) 2 (C 2 O 4 ) 4 (H 2 O) 2 ] 2. The preparation of 2 follows the procedure described for [BaCr2(phen)2(C2O4)4(H2O)2]·4H2O, but the slow evaporation of the resulting solution took place at about 30−40 °C. Anal.:  calcd for C32H20BaCr2N4O18 C, 38.8; H, 2.02; N, 5.65. Found:  C, 38.8; H, 2.6; N, 5.7. IR (KBr, cm-1):  3485 (s), 3081 (w), 1711 (vs), 1684 (s), 1659 (s), 1517 (w), 1395 (vs), 1250 (m), 1143 (w), 857 (m), 810 (m), 724 (m), 552 (m).

[Mn(4,4‘-bipy) 2 (H 2 O) 4 ][Cr(phen)(C 2 O 4 ) 2 ] 2 · 9H 2 O 3. A suspension of 2 (1.0 mmol) in 10 mL of water was reacted with the stoichiometric amount of MnSO4·H2O (1.0 mmol) dissolved in 10 mL of water. The resulting mixture was stirred for 4 h to promote the complete precipitation of the barium sulfate, which was removed by filtration. An ethanolic solution of 4,4‘-bipyridine (2.0 mmol, 10 mL) was added to the red filtrate and the resulting solution was left undisturbed at room temperature. A first crop of red-violet prisms of 3 were formed after one week. Anal.:  Calcd for C52H58Cr2MnN8O29 (3):  C, 44.01; H, 4.09; N, 7.89%. Found:  C, 44.17; H, 4.15; N, 7.9%. IR (KBr, cm-1):  3454 (s), 3329 (s), 3233 (s), 3092 (s), 1713 (vs), 1682 (vs), 1598 (m), 1516 (w), 1398 (s), 1374 (s), 1240 (m), 1145 (w), 1109 (w), 1065 (w), 997 (w), 856 (m), 808 (m), 723 (m), 619 (w), 548 (m).
